CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Effective investigation) (Procedural aspect)
JUDGES: Egidijus Kūris;Ganna Yudkivska;Krzysztof Wojtyczek;Nona Tsotsoria;Paulo Pinto De Albuquerque;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Gabriele Kucsko-Stadlmayer
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . As an officer in a subunit of the special anti - terrorist unit within the special forces for State security ( hereinafter “ the ORG ” ) , the applicant participated in the events which commenced in GPE on DATE and led to the fall of the PERSON dictatorship on DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant was arrested by army forces and held in detention from CARDINAL DATE until DATE . He was then held by the unit ’s commander from DATE until DATE . During this period of time , he was subjected to ill - treatment and , as a result , he suffered depression and he was placed on the officers reserve list on the grounds of poor health ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a criminal complaint with the military prosecutor , alleging that he had been ill - treated and illegally detained in the ORG building and requesting the punishment of various officials , including the unit ’s commander , G.A. The military prosecutor questioned the defendants and a large number of witnesses during the criminal investigation and gathered medical evidence .

CARDINAL . On DATE the military prosecutor found that the unit ’s commander PERSON had been responsible for the applicant ’s deprivation of liberty and his injuries ; however , criminal proceedings could not be initiated because the commander had died .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant asked the military prosecutor to extend the investigation to other officials he alleged were involved , including doctor GPE and various ORG officers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the military prosecutor decided not to initiate criminal proceedings against the doctor P.I. on the ground that the constituent elements of the alleged offence were not present . Following the applicant ’s appeal , this decision was set aside by a decision of CARDINAL DATE and the investigation continued .

CARDINAL . On DATE the military prosecutor found doctor GPE liable to pay an administrative fine ; however , the type of offence he committed had been pardoned by a decree of DATE . The military prosecutor discontinued the investigation in respect of the dead defendant , G.A. The criminal case related to the other defendants , the ORG officers , was severed into separate proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the military prosecutor decided not to initiate criminal proceedings against some of the defendants as the applicant ’s complaint had become partly statute - barred . The investigation into crimes allegedly committed by CARDINAL of the defendants was severed and jurisdiction was relinquished to the prosecuting authorities at ORG and ORG in order to be joined to the main criminal investigation into the events of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the applicant was heard as a witness and as a civil party in the main criminal investigation .

CARDINAL . The most important procedural steps taken in the main criminal investigation are summarised in ORG “ DATE ” and Others v. GPE ( nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL , LAW CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE ) , and ORG v. GPE ( nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL others , § § CARDINAL , DATE ) . Subsequent developments are as follows .
CARDINAL . Following the entry into force of the new Code of Criminal Procedure in DATE , jurisdiction over the case was relinquished in favour of the military prosecutor ’s office .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor ’s office closed the main investigation , finding that the complaints were partly statute - barred and partly ill - founded . The parties have not submitted any information on whether there was an appeal against that decision .
